name: compile
description: Compile a React component to a string with the Onedoc print styles.

files.name: compile

default.description:
A simple function to compile a React component to an HTML string with the Onedoc print styles.
          ```jsx
          const html = await compile(<Component />);
          ```

emotion.description:
Pass `{ emotion: true }` as the second compile option to merge and extract critical CSS using Emotion. Some libraries such as Chakra UI require this option to work correctly.

```jsx
const html = await compile(<Component />, { emotion: true });
```
emotion.name: Emotion CSS

name: CSS
description:
Allows adding CSS to the document while securely parsing and escaping it.

NB: While you can add regular CSS with the `<style>` tag, it's recommended to use the `CSS` component to ensure that the CSS is properly escaped, most notably when using URLs or other potentially unsafe content.

files.name: CSS

default.description: Use a simple CSS tag to support CSS in your document.

files.name: Font

default.name: Load a Google Font
default.description: Load a Google Font its URL. This will allow you to use the font in your document.

props.children: This text uses the Roboto Light font.

default.templateString:
(

This text uses the Roboto Light font.

)

files.name: Margins

default.name: Layout
default.description: Set the page ratio and margin sizes in px. You can also use the `@page` at-rule in CSS to manage all aspects of printed pages. More on this [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/CSS/@page).
default.templateString:
( {`body{background-color:lightblue}`}
Hello world!
 )

files.name: Footnote

children: This is a footnote to explaning what CSS

props.children: CSS is the acronym of “Cascading Style Sheets”. CSS is a computer language for laying out and structuring web pages (HTML or XML).

default.templateString: This is a footnote to explaning what CSS CSS is the acronym of “Cascading Style Sheets”. CSS is a computer language for laying out and structuring web pages (HTML or XML). is.

name: LaTeX
description:
Render LaTeX formulas right in your React components.

<Warning>
LaTeX rendering is still in beta. Please report any issues you encounter on our [Discord](https://discord.com/invite/uRJE6e2rgr).
</Warning>

<Note>Rendering LaTeX using KaTeX requires pulling a remote stylesshet hosted by jsdelivr. This is done to prevent the styles from being purged.</Note>

<Tip>You can use `String.raw` to avoid escaping LaTeX backslashes.</Tip>

files.name: Latex

default.description: Use a simple Latex tag to support Latex in your document.

complex.description: Write complex LaTeX formulas in your document.

props.children:
% \f is defined as #1f(#2) using the macro
\f\relax{x} = \int_{-\infty}^\infty
    \f\hat\xi\,e^{2 \pi i \xi x}
    \,d\xi

name: Markdown
description:
Render Markdown inside your templates. Provides a simple wrapper around [`markdown-to-jsx`](https://github.com/quantizor/markdown-to-jsx).

Markdown allows you to easily separate content from the layout, making it easier to maintain and update your templates. You can pull in content from a CMS or other sources, and use Markdown to format it.

You can also use custom components and variables to make your Markdown more dynamic. For example, you can replace Markdown components with your own components, or use variables to insert dynamic content.

files.name: Markdown

default.description: Use a simple Markdown tag to support Markdown in your document.

props.children:
# Hello, world!

> This is a blockquote

---

This is a paragraph with a [link](https://google.com)

default.templateString:
(
            <Markdown>{`# Hello, world!

> This is a blockquote

---

This is a paragraph with a [link](https://google.com)`}</Markdown>
          )

customComponent.name: Custom Components and Variables
customComponent.description: You can leverage the `overrides` prop to replace Markdown components with your own components. This is useful for custom components or even for dynamic content.

props.children: This content will not be split between two pages.

default.templateString: <NoBreak>This content will not be split between two pages.</NoBreak>

name: Signature
description:
Add signature fields to your document. You can specify various types of fields like signature, initials, date, and more.

<Warning>
Signature and form filling are currently only available to select customers. If you would like to use these features in your project, please reach out at contact@onedoclabs.com.
</Warning>

files.name: Field
files.markdown:
--- title: Field --- Support
Client-side
Server-side
#### Preview The created fields can be signed as-is in Acrobat Reader or other PDF viewers, using Onedoc's signature API, or through other e-signature services like [DocuSign](https://developers.docusign.com/docs/esign-rest-api/esign101/concepts/tabs/pdf-transform/). Supported fields: | Field Type | Description | |------------|-------------| | signHere | Signature field | | signHereOptional | Optional signature field | | signInitialHere | Initials field | | signInitialHereOptional | Optional initials field | | company | Company name field | | dateSigned | Date signed field | | title | Title field | | fullName | Full name field | | lastName | Last name field | | firstName | First name field | | emailAddress | Email address field | | number | Number field | | date | Date field | | ssn | Social Security Number field | | zip5 | ZIP code field | | zip5dash4 | ZIP code with 4-digit extension field | | note | Note field | | list | List field | | checkbox | Checkbox field | | radio | Radio button field | | approve | Approve button field | | decline | Decline button field | | view | View button field | | signerAttachment | Signer attachment field | | signerAttachmentOptional | Optional signer attachment field |
```jsx import { Field } from "@fileforge/react-print"; <>

### Examples

default.description:
The created fields can be signed as-is in Acrobat Reader or other PDF viewers, using Onedoc's signature API, or through other e-signature services like [DocuSign](https://developers.docusign.com/docs/esign-rest-api/esign101/concepts/tabs/pdf-transform/).

|------------|-------------|

| signHereOptional | Optional signature field |

name: Tailwind
description:
A simple, drop-in way to use Tailwind CSS in your components.

<Warning>
The supported Tailwind version is 3.3.2 due to changes in the PostCSS plugin synchronicity.
</Warning>

files.name: Tailwind

default.description: Use a simple Tailwind tag to support Tailwind in your document.

props.children: This is a Tailwind component. All children of this component will have access to the Tailwind CSS classes.

default.templateString:
(

This is a Tailwind component. All children of this component will have access to the Tailwind CSS classes.

)

config.name: Custom Tailwind config
config.description: You can also pass a custom Tailwind config to the Tailwind component.

props.children: This is a Tailwind component. All children of this component will have access to the Tailwind CSS classes.

name: Variables
description: Display dynamic values based on your document, such as page numbers and running headers.

files.name: PageNumber

customStyle.description: You can use a custom CSS counter-style, by passing a known name or a custom counter style.

files.name: PagesNumber
RunningH1

default.description: Show the current running header of level 1 in the page header. All running headers are reset when any of their parent headings are encountered (e.g. a level 2 heading resets the level 3, 4, 5 and 6 headings).

files.name: RunningH2
files.markdown:
--- title: RunningH2 --- Returns the current page's running header of level 2. Support
Client-side
Server-side
```jsx import { RunningH2 } from "@fileforge/react-print"; ```
